title: 104_hr925
content: The "Private Property Protection Act of 1995" ensures that no law or agency action should diminish the value of privately owned property. Federal agencies must exercise authority to prevent such limitations and property owners have the right to compensation. The Federal Government must compensate property owners if an agency action diminishes the property's value by 20% or more. If the value decreases by over 50%, the government can buy the affected portion at fair market value. Once compensation is received, the property cannot be used against the agency's limitation, even if the action is later revoked. Property owners must be compensated if an agency action reduces their property value by 20% or more. If the value decreases by over 50%, the government can purchase the affected portion at fair market value. Once compensation is received, the property cannot be used against the agency's limitation, even if the action is later revoked. SEC. 4. EFFECT OF STATE LAW. If a use is a nuisance or prohibited by local zoning, no compensation under this Act. SEC. 5. EXCEPTIONS. No compensation for actions preventing hazards or damage to specific property. No compensation for agency actions under Federal navigation servitude, except for wetlands. SEC. 6. PROCEDURE. An owner must request compensation from the agency within 180 days of receiving notice of the agency action. The agency can negotiate the compensation amount with the owner, and if no agreement is reached within 180 days, the owner can choose arbitration or a civil action for compensation. Arbitration procedures will be similar to those under title 9, United States Code. If parties do not agree on compensation, owner can opt for arbitration or civil action. Arbitration procedures will be similar to those under title 9, United States Code. An award in arbitration includes attorney's fees and other costs. Owner can seek relief in civil action if arbitration is not chosen or if prompt payment is not received. Successful civil action entitles owner to reasonable compensation from the agency. An owner who does not opt for arbitration or receive prompt payment can seek relief through a civil action against the agency. In a successful civil action, the owner is entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on compensation. Payments and judgments in civil actions are sourced from the agency's annual appropriation. In a civil action, an owner can obtain judgment against an agency, with payment sourced from the agency's annual appropriation. If the agency's action was due to another agency's requirement, reimbursement can be sought. The agency head can transfer funds if needed, and if funds are insufficient, the agency head must seek appropriation for the next fiscal year. SEC. 7. LIMITATION. Any payment under this Act by the United States is subject to the availability of appropriations. SEC. 8. DUTY OF NOTICE TO OWNERS. Agencies must notify property owners affected by limitations on property use, explaining their rights and compensation procedures under this Act. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 8. DUTY OF NOTICE TO OWNERS. Agencies must notify property owners affected by limitations on property use, explaining their rights and compensation procedures under this Act. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. Nothing in this Act limits any right to compensation under the Constitution or other U.S. laws. Payment of compensation does not grant the Federal Government any additional rights. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. The term "property" in this Act refers to land and the right to use or receive water. A use of property is limited by agency action if a legal right to use the property no longer exists due to the action. The term "agency action" includes making a grant to a public authority conditioned upon an action that would limit property rights. The term "specified regulatory law" includes section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The term "specified regulatory law" refers to specific laws such as the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act, the Food Security Act, and the Reclamation Acts. The term "fair market value" is defined as the most probable price at which property would change hands between a willing buyer and a willing seller, under fair market conditions. This definition is specified in laws such as the Reclamation Acts, the Federal Land Policy Management Act, and the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act. The term "fair market value" is defined as the most probable price at which property would change hands between a willing buyer and a willing seller, under fair market conditions. This definition is specified in laws such as the Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 3, 1995. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
